channel.title: @hyperdbg - Telegram group archive
channel.description: Public archive of HyperDbg Telegram messages.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-07-18 04:21:16+00:00 (#7233)
item.description: I think for the thread variant it's better to patch the execution flow (e.g. some assembly codes at @rip or somewhere else), but for the VMX-root variant, I'll try to see what's the best method of adding such a function.

item.title: @395437265 on 2024-07-17 18:11:18+00:00 (#7231)
item.description: maybe for single thread will be more useful

item.title: @395437265 on 2024-07-17 18:10:53+00:00 (#7230)
item.description: im fine with both variants

item.title: @395437265 on 2024-07-17 18:10:14+00:00 (#7229)
item.description: mm depends whats simplier :)

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-07-17 17:18:54+00:00 (#7228)
item.description: No problem, I could implement that, but just to confirm it with you, do you expect to sleep() and halt the entire core for a couple of seconds or do you want to make sleep() only the target thread?

item.title: @395437265 on 2024-07-17 16:56:08+00:00 (#7227)
item.description: Timer problem not, but recursive call is

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-07-17 16:09:01+00:00 (#7226)
item.description: Oh, the problem is solved now?

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-07-17 16:08:41+00:00 (#7225)
item.description: No, I mean a function in the script engine.

item.title: @395437265 on 2024-07-16 19:05:36+00:00 (#7224)
item.description: it recursively calls same sub 00D6A7AD in this case 5 times, and then exits

item.title: @395437265 on 2024-07-16 19:05:06+00:00 (#7223)
@395437265 on 2024-07-16 19:02:54+00:00 (#7222)
item.description: @HughEverett for now, my goal is achieved :) thanks once again for this great tool. i will continue to explore this app so i can find even more exploits

item.title: @395437265 on 2024-07-16 15:53:31+00:00 (#7221)
item.description: looks interesting, i can execute it from code{} part, right ?

item.title: @395437265 on 2024-07-16 15:52:36+00:00 (#7220)
item.description: i dont need high precision in my case

item.title: @395437265 on 2024-07-16 15:52:13+00:00 (#7219)
@HughEverett on 2024-07-16 13:57:30+00:00 (#7218)
item.description: What about a function for RDTSC/P? 🤨

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-07-16 13:57:10+00:00 (#7217)
item.description: Only time in milis doesn't make sense since it will change each time you try to get it and it takes a long time to be ready (like some functions needed to be called) which makes it not a suitable case.

item.title: @395437265 on 2024-07-15 19:54:35+00:00 (#7216)
item.description: @HughEverett looks like i found solution about timer - can you pls add $timeD that returns time as milis, but not string, then by using global vars i can manage timing easily

item.title: @395437265 on 2024-07-15 18:16:50+00:00 (#7215)
item.description: ah.. i thought its related to timer somehow, of course i used monitors for pid with sc :)

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-07-15 18:12:47+00:00 (#7214)
item.description:
Another option is using the newly added !mode command+event_sc:
https://docs.hyperdbg.org/commands/extension-commands/mode

item.title: @395437265 on 2024-07-15 18:12:02+00:00 (#7212)
item.description: i just thought about sc :)

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-07-15 18:11:21+00:00 (#7211)
item.description: This one. You can use the short-circuiting mechanisom along with the !monitor's X attribute to pause the target process.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-07-15 18:10:24+00:00 (#7210)
item.description: https://youtu.be/Z6HAO4btkCM?si=UXqIFckLW2fpeIIv

item.title: @395437265 on 2024-07-15 18:09:21+00:00 (#7209)
item.description: yes, maybe i missed something when watched

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-07-15 18:08:52+00:00 (#7208)
item.description: There are tons of way to do this. Let me find an example from OST2 videos

item.title: @395437265 on 2024-07-15 18:08:44+00:00 (#7207)
item.description: i mean use sleep implementation as reference

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-07-15 18:08:17+00:00 (#7206)
item.description: HyperDbg is in VMX root-mode, not user-mode 😕

item.title: @395437265 on 2024-07-15 18:05:07+00:00 (#7205)
item.description: call kernel32!SleepEx(time,0). it will break current process for time milis

item.title: @395437265 on 2024-07-15 18:04:17+00:00 (#7204)
item.description: in assembly its quite simple to do :D

item.title: @395437265 on 2024-07-15 18:03:39+00:00 (#7203)
item.description: (i dont know 64bit windows call)

item.title: @395437265 on 2024-07-15 18:03:20+00:00 (#7202)
item.description: about timer - kernel32!GetTickCount might help

item.title: @395437265 on 2024-07-15 18:02:53+00:00 (#7201)
item.description: ah... but i need it only for one process, so it wont stop execution of whole vm

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-07-15 18:01:09+00:00 (#7200)
item.description: Don't have any idea how it's implemented in the OS-level functions or how we can implement it in VMX root-mode. 🤔 Does it need a timer configuration? 🤨

item.title: @395437265 on 2024-07-15 17:58:11+00:00 (#7199)
item.description: like pause() wait some time and resume

item.title: @395437265 on 2024-07-15 17:57:56+00:00 (#7198)
item.description: @HughEverett i also wanted to ask - is it possible to implement sleep(x) in script, so it pauses execution for x miliseconds?

item.title: @395437265 on 2024-07-15 17:48:55+00:00 (#7197)
item.description: i will give a try to call eb within script, maybe antidebug wont detect it instantly, so i will manage o put code back :) but there are aligment problems for sure

item.title: @395437265 on 2024-07-15 17:47:57+00:00 (#7196)
item.description: thats good, but seems wont fix my situation :)

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-07-15 17:46:26+00:00 (#7195)
item.description: FYI, @Reverser69 is now working on bringing the support for assembly codes (keystone) within code {} statements, along with its classic hex format.

item.title: @395437265 on 2024-07-15 17:45:05+00:00 (#7194)
item.description: epthooks are always detected.. not instantly, but after some time

item.title: @395437265 on 2024-07-15 17:43:59+00:00 (#7193)
item.description: yes, thinking about playing with stack, its a pity, that code {} execution is in vmx-root...

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-07-15 17:31:43+00:00 (#7192)
item.description: The thing that you wanna do, seems more reasonable to be done by using an !epthook. But as probably you're dealing with an executable with lots of anti debugging methods, maybe modifying the stack and putting the return address of a CALL gadget works for this case?

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-07-15 17:29:03+00:00 (#7191)
item.description: So, I don't have any idea what's going on inside HyperDbg with a post stage !monitor to a CALL instruction. 🤔

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-07-15 17:28:11+00:00 (#7190)
item.description: This MTF will be executed exactly after one instruction. It doesn't work like a step-over, it's like a step-in.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-07-15 17:27:21+00:00 (#7189)
item.description: I was thinking about it. The thing is, after executing a call (pre stage), an MTF is set to bring the results back (post stage).

item.title: @395437265 on 2024-07-15 06:57:53+00:00 (#7188)
item.description: I actually want to call next instruction after monitored address.. I used stage post, because on monitored instruction parameter for call was set, so it will be set up properly..

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-07-15 05:35:59+00:00 (#7187)
item.description:
No, actually if you wanna call something within an event, it'll be called from VMX root-mode. Though, not sure if it's because you're using it in the post stage or not.
Can you put the '!monitor' check into the next address (the address after the current @eip) and use it in the regular 'pre' stage?

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-07-15 05:32:28+00:00 (#7185)
item.description:
Starting from v0.10 (the next version), HyperDbg uses @keystone_engine as its assembler. ❤️
Thanks to our new team member @Reverser69 for adding it.
The following commands are added to assemble virtual and physical memory:
- https://docs.hyperdbg.org/commands/debugging-commands/a
- https://docs.hyperdbg.org/commands/extension-commands/a

item.title: @395437265 on 2024-07-15 04:45:09+00:00 (#7184)
item.description: It's 32 bit app I'm trying to reverse )

item.title: @395437265 on 2024-07-15 04:44:48+00:00 (#7183)
item.description: App crash, hyberdbg is just fine. Yea, just got it that changing eip within one execution is pointless. Is there another way to call some code from script? Like xdbg script .asm sections?

item.title: @grootdxb on 2024-07-15 00:20:29+00:00 (#7182)
item.description: Why the hell is it "EIP" — 32 bit!? PLLLEASE STOP with 32-bit for the love of all thats Holy and precious.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-07-14 23:33:38+00:00 (#7181)
item.description: But, that's definitely not a reason for the crash. Is it a crash of HyperDbg (BSOD)? or the target program crashes through SEH?

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-07-14 23:32:23+00:00 (#7180)
@395437265 on 2024-07-14 21:43:27+00:00 (#7179)
@HughEverett on 2024-07-14 14:08:23+00:00 (#7178)
item.description: Ok, got it. I'll check it with these new details. Thanks 👍

item.title: @395437265 on 2024-07-13 20:28:39+00:00 (#7177)
item.description: e.g. if new thread is spawn within call, then p cant detect ret properly, maybe some cpu optimizations, so thread is started and control flow now belongs to thread, so it wont return until thread is complete (if ever), but thats just assumptions

item.title: @395437265 on 2024-07-13 20:25:54+00:00 (#7176)
item.description: in general, it seems, that p bug is related to threading

item.title: @395437265 on 2024-07-13 20:24:36+00:00 (#7175)
item.description: @HughEverett sorry, i have no time currently, i think i can implement some deterministic test in asm, but it need me to remember asm :) i studied it almost 15 yrs ago, lot of thing have changed, chatgpt also not helping much, but i got some ideas already

item.title: @grootdxb on 2024-07-13 12:35:04+00:00 (#7174)
item.description: Thats "mov >Q<word" — anyway, assuming RSP is not broken (corrupted or otherwise), thats no different than. uint64_t foo; foo=0; or uint64_t foo, uint64_t * bar=&foo; *bar=0

item.title: @xmaple555 on 2024-07-13 04:59:09+00:00 (#7173)
item.description: the rsp pointing to mov dword ptr [rsp +40h],0 (UINT Index = 0)

item.title: @xmaple555 on 2024-07-13 04:57:39+00:00 (#7172)
item.description: I use Debug mode to compile . I guess the optimization is off

item.title: @grootdxb on 2024-07-12 23:07:46+00:00 (#7171)
item.description: As far as "no line showing" —- likely due to optimizations..add #pragma optimize("", off) to the top of the C/CPP and compile/run again

item.title: @grootdxb on 2024-07-12 23:07:02+00:00 (#7170)
item.description: Literally... if RSP is valid, (Assuming its some local var), then...the line you listed is simply moving 0 (zero) into the local var, and not invalid. If RSP (the stack) is jacked up, then you've got some problem elsewhere.

item.title: @xmaple555 on 2024-07-12 21:10:08+00:00 (#7169)
item.description: any solution ? 😢

item.title: @xmaple555 on 2024-07-12 21:09:38+00:00 (#7168)
item.description: only show yellow arrow to the current line in asm

item.title: @xmaple555 on 2024-07-12 21:08:49+00:00 (#7167)
item.description: hi guys, I'm trying to use visual studio kernel debug. But there is no current line shown (yellow arrow) in source code when hitting breakpoint

item.title: @395437265 on 2024-07-12 14:34:45+00:00 (#7166)
item.description: sure, no prob

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-07-12 05:19:15+00:00 (#7165)
item.description: I'll create a GitHub issue to further investigate it. Meanwhile, if you find a deterministic way of reproducing it, pls let me know.

item.description: It's on the 'dev' branch now. Sure we won't release (merge it to the master) if the problem is not yet fixed.

item.description: @HughEverett no good :( it solved the issue i mentioned, i can quit waiting with ctrl+c, but introduced another - if i put bp on call instruction and when bp is trapped, when i press p it just continues execution

item.title: @6190448061 on 2024-07-10 11:25:38+00:00 (#7148)
item.description: You did a great job.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-07-10 07:09:43+00:00 (#7147)
item.description:
Eduard I fixed this issue, but I'm not sure if I correctly fixed it and it didn't break anything. Once you have free time, please update your 'dev' branch and make a comprehensive test on both the step-over 'p' and the step-in 't', and let me know if you find any problems.
https://github.com/HyperDbg/HyperDbg/issues/406

item.title: @395437265 on 2024-07-08 17:09:13+00:00 (#7145)

item.title: @395437265 on 2024-07-08 08:56:23+00:00 (#7143)

item.title: @395437265 on 2024-07-08 07:04:24+00:00 (#7141)

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-07-08 07:00:52+00:00 (#7140)
@HughEverett on 2024-07-08 06:29:10+00:00 (#7139)
item.description: I'll keep testing the same scripts to find a way for reproducing it, meanwhile if you find a reproduceable sequence of command, pls send it here.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-07-08 06:27:53+00:00 (#7138)
item.description: But, only one time! Couldn't reproduce it again. It seems to be race condition but in order to investigate it, it needs to be deterministically reproduced.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-07-08 06:26:36+00:00 (#7136)
item.description:
I was not able to reproduce the error using your scripts in the GitHub, but it was reproduced once using this script:
.sym reload pid 3024 .process pid 3024 g .process !monitor x ws2_32!send l 3 script { printf("pre triggered\n"); } -------------------------------------- g event c all g .process pid 3024 g .process -------------------------------------- bp ws2_32!send !monitor x ws2_32!send l 3 script { printf("pre triggered\n"); } .process

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-07-08 03:54:19+00:00 (#7134)
item.description: https://x.com/HyperDbg/status/1810158816136487361

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-07-07 10:53:34+00:00 (#7133)
